description: From Middle English tool, tol, from Old English tōl (“tool, implement, instrument”, literally “that with which one prepares something”), from Proto-West Germanic *tōl, from Proto-Germanic *tōlą (“that which is used in preparation, tool”), from Proto-Indo-European *dewh₂- (“to tie to, secure”), equivalent to taw (“to prepare”) +‎ -le (agent suffix). Cognate with Scots tuil (“tool, implement, instrument, device”), Icelandic tól (“tool”), Faroese tól (“tool, instrument”). Related to Old English tāwian (“to make, prepare, or cultivate”); see taw, and tow ("fibres used for spinning").

entries.meaning: A mechanical device intended to make a task easier.
examples: Hand me that tool, would you?
I don't have the right tools to start fiddling around with the engine.

entries.meaning: Any piece of equipment used in a profession, e.g. a craftman's tools.
examples: These are the tools of the trade.

entries.meaning: Something to perform an operation; an instrument; a means.
(computing) A piece of software used to develop software or hardware, or to perform low-level operations.
examples: The software engineer had been developing lots of EDA tools.
a tool for recovering deleted files from a disk

entries.meaning: A person or group which is used or controlled, usually unwittingly, by another person or group.
examples: He was a tool, no more than a pawn to her.

entries.meaning: (by extension, vulgar, slang, derogatory) An obnoxious or uptight person.
examples: He won't sell us tickets because it's 3:01, and they went off sale at 3. That guy's such a tool.

entries.meaning: (vulgar, slang) A penis, notably with a sexual or erotic connotation.
(slang, Canada, US, MTE, MLE, and possibly wider) A gun.

verbs.description: tool (third-person singular simple present tools, present participle tooling, simple past and past participle tooled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To work on or shape with tools, e.g., hand-tooled leather.

examples: Do this lab and read this book, now tool, one and all,And be sure and pass that final quiz or be screwed right to the wall.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To put down another person (possibly in a subtle, hidden way), and in that way to use him or her to meet a goal.
examples: Dude, he's not your friend. He's just tooling you.

entries.meaning: (transitive, volleyball) To intentionally attack the ball so that it deflects off a blocker out of bounds.
(transitive, UK, slang, dated) To drive (a coach or other vehicle).
(transitive, UK, slang, dated) To carry or convey in a coach or other vehicle.
examples: Among those who seemed disposed to join in this opinion was the Jehu of the Warwickshire coach, who expressed his conviction to our hero, that "he wos a young gent as had much himproved hisself since he tooled him up to the Warsity with his guvnor."

entries.meaning: (intransitive, slang) To travel in a vehicle; to ride or drive.
examples: boys on their bicycles tooling along the well-kept roads
